grounding: Despite the fact that oil chemistry and oils spills have been studied for many years, there are still emerging techniques and unknown processes to be explored. The 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico resulted in a revival of oil spill research across a wide range of fields. These studies provided many new insights, but unanswered questions remain. Over 1,000 journal articles related to the Deepwater Horizon spill are indexed by the Chemical Abstract Service. Numerous ecological, human health, and organismal studies were published. Analytical tools applied to the spill include mass spectrometry, chromatography, and optical spectroscopy. Owing to the large scale of studies, this review focuses on three emerging areas that have been explored but remain underutilized in oil spill characterization: excitation-emission matrix spectroscopy, black carbon analysis, and trace metal analysis using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry.
generated_text: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill has underscored the need for advanced analytical techniques to understand the environmental impact of petroleum and petroleum-derived dissolved organic matter (DOM). This study explores emerging chemical methods, including inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and fluorescence spectroscopy, for the characterization of petrogenic DOM and black carbon in marine environments. ICP-MS offers unparalleled sensitivity and specificity for trace metal analysis, providing insights into the geochemical cycling of elements associated with petroleum. Fluorescence spectroscopy, on the other hand, enables the identification and quantification of complex organic compounds, shedding light on the transformation and degradation processes of DOM. Together, these techniques offer a comprehensive toolkit for assessing the environmental fate of petroleum-derived compounds, facilitating the development of more effective remediation strategies and enhancing our understanding of the ecological consequences of oil spills.
